name: Italy
description: A hand gesture where the thumb is placed between the index and middle fingers. Used for protection against evil eye (malocchio) or as an obscene gesture depending on context.

name: Portugal
description: Traditional protective gesture against evil eye. Also sold as amulets.

name: Brazil
description: Widely used protective gesture inherited from Portuguese tradition. Often worn as jewelry or amulet for good luck.

name: Turkey
description: While not exactly mano fico, similar protective hand gestures exist against the evil eye (nazar).

name: Greece
description: Ancient protective gesture documented in classical antiquity. Used against evil eye and malevolent forces.

name: Spain
description: Traditional gesture and amulet for protection. Common in Spanish folklore.

name: Sicily
description: Particularly strong tradition in Sicily for warding off the evil eye. Often depicted in ancient amulets.

name: Ancient Rome
description: Ancient Roman protective amulet. Archaeological evidence shows widespread use throughout Roman Empire.

name: Netherlands
description: Historical usage documented in medieval and early modern period, though less common today.

name: Germany
description: Historical gesture with documented use in medieval Germany. Now largely obsolete.

name: Russia
description: Traditional gesture with protective and offensive meanings. Also called 'dulya' or 'kukish'.

name: Serbia
description: Gesture known as 'smokva' (fig), used as both protective charm and insult.
